awd_titl_txt: CAREER: Fracture Mechanics of Soft Dissipative Materials
awd_abstract_narration:
This Faculty Early Career Development Program (CAREER) award will support fundamental research on the fracture resistance of soft elastomers and hydrogels. Soft materials that can undergo large reversible deformation have been widely utilized in industrial applications such as tires and soft adhesives, or emerging technologies such as soft robots, biomedical implants and stretchable display. In these applications, the underlying soft materials are required to be stretchable to enable functionality and yet fracture resistant to enhance reliability. Driven by this need, various physical or chemical mechanisms have been developed to enhance the fracture resistance of soft materials, and they share a common theme: to introduce energy dissipation or consumption by the material during deformation. However, theoretical modeling and experimental characterization of fracture in such soft dissipative materials are challenging due to the lack of understandings on the quantitative relation between energy dissipation and fracture resistance. This research program will establish experimental and modeling capabilities to uncover the complex nonlinear mechanics associated with soft material fracture, which will lead to quantitative principles for engineering new soft functional materials that are mechanically robust, as well as new tools to measure and predict fracture in soft materials. Thus, the research will promote the science of soft material fracture to advance the national health, prosperity, and welfare. As part of research, education and outreach programs will be developed to promote research of soft material fracture in academic, educational and industrial sectors by creating an interdisciplinary summer workshop, integrating research findings into curriculum and K-12 outreach activities, and building collaborations with industrial partners.

A major challenge in soft material fracture is the large deformation near the tip of a crack, which causes nonlinear strain and stress fields as well as complex failure and dissipation behaviors. To address this challenge, a particle tracking method will be used to measure the crack tip deformation field in model soft materials under various fracture modes. For elastic materials, the experiments will provide data to assess the region of validity for existing crack tip asymptotic solutions, to discover new structures of crack tip fields, and to enable local evaluation of energy release rate through the J-integral, thus eliminating the requirement of specialized experimental geometries. For dissipative materials, the experimental data of crack tip deformation field, augmented by accurate constitutive models, will be used to identify the crack tip dissipation zone and to separately measure the intrinsic and dissipative toughness. A finite element model will also be developed to couple the crack tip failure process, represented by a cohesive zone, with the bulk material dissipation, which will enable the prediction of crack growth in soft dissipative materials.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
Fundamental understandings on the fracture resistance of soft elastomers and hydrogels underlie a myriad of existing and emerging applications, ranging from tires and adhesives to soft robotics and biomedical implants. A sharp crack in soft materials can induce large deformation that is highly non-uniform and localized around the crack tip, which further causes complex damage and dissipation behaviors. This project aimed to uncover the intricate nonlinear mechanics associated with soft material fracture by integrating experimental measurement, theoretical modeling and computational simulation.  

Specifically, the objectives of this project were to: 1) measure the two-dimensional (2D) crack tip deformation field in soft elastic or dissipative materials; 2) acquire experimental data to reveal the criterion for mixed-mode crack growth in soft elastomers; 3) establish theoretical models for estimating the dissipative toughness; 4) measure the three-dimensional (3D) crack tip deformation field in soft materials with confocal imaging; 5) develop finite element models for predictive simulation of crack propagation in soft dissipative materials; 6) broaden the impact of research through educational and outreach activities. These objectives were met at the end of the project period. The outcomes associated with these objectives are listed below.

Experimental characterization of 2D fracture in soft materials: we have established and validated a particle tracking method to map the nonlinear deformation fields during crack propagation. This versatile method was first demonstrated for a predominantly elastic silicone elastomer, and was then used to map the fields of deformation and energy dissipation during the fracture of various inelastic soft materials, including viscoelastic polyampholyte hydrogels, optically clear pressure sensitive adhesive films, and filled styrene-butadiene rubbers. These measurements enabled the quantification of how energy dissipation around a propagating crack tip enhances the fracture resistance in soft materials.

Mixed-mode crack growth in soft elastomers: using the particle tracking method, we successfully measured the crack tip deformation field for mixed-mode (Mode I and II) cracks in a silicone elastomer. Based on these measurements, we characterized the fracture toughness under different mixed-mode conditions and determined the criterion for crack propagation direction. This approach was also extended to study the interaction between a growing crack and a stiff inclusion in a silicone elastomer, which provided mechanistic insights on how the inclusion affects the extent and direction of crack propagation by altering the stress field around the crack.

Theory of soft material fracture: we established a general theoretical framework to calculate the energy dissipation associated with crack propagation in soft dissipative materials. Using this framework, we derived relation between the dissipative and intrinsic components of fracture toughness in soft materials exhibiting the Mullins softening behavior, and verified it using finite element simulations. This framework was also applied to viscoelastic materials to calculate the energy dissipation associated with crack growth under static or cyclic loadings. Based on this framework, a theory to predict the rate of cyclic crack growth in viscoelastic materials was established, which has important implications in understanding the fatigue fracture of viscoelastic solids. More broadly, theoretical efforts were carried out to understand the length scales involved in soft material fracture and the damage behavior in soft polymer networks.

3D effects of soft material fracture: we developed an experimental apparatus to enable volumetric confocal imaging in transparent soft elastomers during crack growth. Using this apparatus and the 3D particle tracking method, we measured the 3D crack profile and the associated strain fields. This has led to new experimental data revealing the intricate 3D structure of crack front in soft materials. In addition, new theoretical insights on how 3D effects cause the dependence of soft material fracture on the specimen thickness were obtained.

Finite element modeling of soft material fracture: we established finite element models to simulate crack growth in soft dissipative materials to support the theoretical efforts. In addition, we broadened our study by applying the computational tools for soft material fracture to problems with more general geometries and loading conditions than crack growth. These problems include adhesion-induced static friction of rigid indenter on soft substrates, friction of textured surfaces, adhesive contact of inflated membranes, interface fracture of hydrogel adhesives, and peeling mechanics of adhesive tapes.

Education and outreach: the fundamental knowledge established in this project has broadly impacted educational and industrial sectors through a series of activities. In particular, a new course on fracture mechanics for senior undergraduate and graduate students was developed, and research findings on soft material fracture from this project were integrated into this course. In addition, this project has led to industrial collaborations with Michelin and 3M in which experimental methodology established from this project was applied to synthetic rubber and pressure sensitive adhesives. The PI also delivered multiple research presentations to audience in these two companies. Impact of this project was further broadened through undergraduate research projects, high school student research, and organization of regional research symposiums.
